p.seg: In what Heaven is a cover over,
in what the Earth supports,
in what Man does,
nothing is greater than zhōng.
In the realm of what is being covered over and supported
it is the main point in human morality.
When one acts according to it that brings good luck,
and when one offends against it that brings bad luck.
There is nothing more important than zhōng.
Zhōng is to be centered/focussed,
it is to be perfectly unselfish/public-minded and to be without personal bias.
If one does not adjust one's mind/attitude
and shows personal bias with respect to matters,
then that is the opposite of zhōng.
Heaven never shows partiality
and the four seasons take their course.
Earth never shows partiality
and the myriad kinds of creatures are generated.
When man never shows partiality
then he will be supremely well adjusted.
The four seasons take their broad course
and Heaven shows no partial generosity.
The myriad kinds of creatures are auspiciously generated
and they Earth does not make a partial effort (on behalf of any of them).
When man is capable of being perfectly impartial
and shows no partiality to things with respect to himself,
then where will he not be all right?
As for zhōng refers toconcentrating the mind.
If the mind is concentrated that counts as zhōng,
and when the mind is divided that counts as deviating (from zhōng)
The basis of running a state,
how can that not flow from zhōng.
One never ever gives up on zhōng
and is successful with regard to the tasks one sets oneself.
Zhōng confirms relations between ruler and minister, gives peace to the nation, moves Heaven and Earth, moves the spirits
and how much more will it move other people.
That rulers and ministers have confirmed relations
is because what is right for them is profoundly established.
That the nation is in peace
is because its good fortune is long-loasting.
That Heaven and Earth are moved,
is because it is truly reached.
That the spirits are moved,
is because their response is manifest.
The application of of zhōng
has an efficacy like this.
And one's words will be easy to follow by others.
Now zhōng comes to flourish in the person,
it manifests itself in the family,
and it comes to fruition in the state:
its functioning/enaction is one and the same in all these cases.
In the cases of the person, as well as the state and the family
although they have different names
as for their constituting zhōng
there is never difference in functioning/enaction.
Therefore the providing of a focus for the person
is the beginning of zhōng.
The providing a focus for the family
is the middle of zhōng.
The providing a focus for the state
is the end of zhōng.
The enaction of the way marks a gradual natural progress,
and in this zhōng grows to its greatness.
When the person is focussed then all benefits arrive.
Establishing one's personality and enacting the focussing
that is the basis for wealth and rank.
When there is a focus in the family then the six family relations will be in harmony.
When in the running of the family there is not divided focus:
things will work naturally and there will be solid harmony.
When the state is focussed then the myriad people are well governed.
Everyone in the world will be adjusted in attitude,
and none will fail to follow the educational transformation.
As the Documents have it:
"Just by being subtle and just by being focussed
one will indeed get to the core of things."
Focussing on the one, guarding carefully what is central,
that is the significance of zhōng.
From below to above (rulers as well as the common people)
each peson has appropriate reverence.
Thus the true king serves Heaven above
he serves the earth below,
and in the middle he serves the ancestral shrines
in order so to deal with his people.
The true kind is the ultimately important person
and still he has something to which he shows appropriate reverence,
how much should those do so who are below.
And so when a person transforms them through education
then everyone under Heaven will do their utmost in zhōng to serve their superior.
The superior acts and the inferiors are transformed:
that is the natural course of government.
King Wen was respectful and obedient, and Yú and Ruì accepting the settlement of their border dispute are cases in point.
Therefor one makes every effort to pay careful attention,
and every day one increases the understanding (of zhōng).
Every day one progesses by one day,
and the virtue becomes more transparent.
One gives apanages to the worthy and office to the capable,
and one makes arrangements for the great transformation.
One's generosity will thus be long-lasting
and the common people will all be touched by it.
Unless they are touched by it they cannot stay with their apanages (but will rebel),
and without educational transformation one cannot cause people to be touched.
Hiring the worthy and deploying the educational transformation,
that is the main task of the ruler.
Thus when one obtains the grandness of imperial educational transformation
and this gets exercised in the four regions
and gets devolved upon later generations
so as to protect the altars of the land and grain/nation
so as glorify the ancestors.
When the ruler is sagely and the ministers are worthy
the news of their enlightened actions are spread abroad
so as to cast glory on the anestors,
so as to make the appropriate sacrifice to the nation, forever.
In fact, such is the zhōng of the sage ruler.
The basic nature of zhōng
is for it to reach everywhere.
As the Songs have it:
"Brightly serving the Di on High
one will enjoy much good fortune."
The ruler serves Heaven through bright virtue
and Heaven gives manifest good fortune to the ruler.
As for the relation between the senior minister and the ruler
they can be said to be (like) one body.
When the lower part acts, the upper part trusts him:
thus it is that one can bring zhōng to fruition.
When the aide moves below
the head follows above:
becvause their sense of justice is the same
therefore their attitudes do not differ.
As for zhōng,
It is not just a matter of serving the ruler and neglecting one's personal interests
/serving/ the state and forgetting about the interests of one's own family,
to keep a straight face and to formulate oneself straightforwardly,
to face up to difficulties and to die for one's values.
All these are ordinary ways of practising zhōng,
and they are certainly what one will normally do,
but they do not exhaust a senior minister's work.
It consists in profound strategic planning and deep deliberations
concerning the straightening out the state and giving peace to men.
Ultimate zhōng leaves no trace:
it truly consists in profound immersion.
If one employs the worthy to run government
one just wears one's ritually prescribed court dress and things are transformed of themselves.
If for each office one finds the right person
what problem is there?
They will venerate the ruler as being as all-encompassing as Heaven and Earth,
and bright as the sun and the moon,
as being as harmonious as Yin and Yang
and as predictable as the four seasons.
He covers over things like Heaven,
encompasses them like Earth,
shines on them like the sun and the moon,
attunes them like Yin and Yang.
Without speaking it is trusted, like the four seasons.
In acting like this
the ruler enacts zhōng completely.
The virtue of the sage is overflowingly vast,
and that is how the elogies on it arise.
They feel delight about it inside
and they act in harmony with it on the outside.
As the Documents have it:
The leader is so enlightened,
his helpers are so excellent,
and all affairs are so well-appointed!
and when the ministers are conpetent all business will be in peaceful balance.
Thus when the gentleman serves superiors,
when at home he hands up his plans.
When it comes to what is profitable to house in charge
then, whatever he knows he will speak up on.
When abroad he enacts the policies (of his ruler).
Since he is in the position
as part of his official duty he is concerned about the (political) worries.
When at rest he reflects on his way.
When taking initiatives it is in accordance with the relevant ritual prescriptions.
I.e. the ritual prescriptions for all the various official tasks.
In taking care of his official duties he does not wince,
in speaking up on official matters he shows no fear.
If he can benefit the nation
then he will disregard his own person.
I someone is sparing with himself and follows a devious course
then that is filling a position without doing the job. 尸位素食
The functions of superiors and subordinates coming to fruition
therefore they will glorify the ruler's virtue.
This, then, is the zhōng of the various specialists.
As the Songs have it:
Peacefully and respectfully occupy your places,
this is the correct and the straight way.
If there is purity, there is no desire,
when there is even-handedness then there is no contortion,
and when there is lucidness one can correct customs.
When these three are provided
only then can one govern others.
That a man of superior character exercises zhōng to the full and is capable of enacting his political programmes,
but that he does not sort out the government,
this is unheard of.
Now all humans desire peace,
and the person of superior character will, in accordance with their desires, provide them the conditions for peace.
Everyone desires wealth,
and the person of superior character will instruct them so as to make them rich.
He will make them morally sturdy through morality
so as to firm up their minds/attitudes.
He will guide them with ritual and music
in order to harmonise their vital energies.
He will propagate the ruler's virutes in order to give greater scope to the educational transformation.
He will make clear the laws of the land in order to reach the stage where there are no punishments.
If one looks at the ruler's men?????????
as if observing one's child
then these men will love him
as they would love their parents.
In fact, this is the zhōng of minister in charge.
When the ruler's virute shines forth brightly
then Yin and Yang, the wind and the rain will be in harmony as a result,
and people will rely on these to propagate themselves.
Therefore serving the ruler's legal measures,
ensuring the practice of filial piety and love in the family,
collecting grain to pay as taxes to the king,
that is the zhōng of the ordinary citizen.
To administrate people through administration,
is the medium form of government,
and as a result people will have no alternative but to do good.
Punishing through corporal punishment
is the lowest form of government
and as a result the people will stand in fearful awe and will not dare to do wrong.
When administering punishments, the point is in using them sparingly and things will be fair..
When conducting administration the point is in simple transparence and they will be effective.
Virtue is the basis for conducting government.
When in administration one is not in accordance with virtue
then one's influence will be slight.
If in availing oneself of punishments one is not in accordance with virtue,
then one will become a menace.
Therefore the superior person will make virtue his business,
will cultivate it in administration
and will be diligent about it in punishment.
When one is firm in one's zhōng
so as to manifest one's devoted good faith,
and when in carrying this out one is never lax
then how could there be disorderly people.
When pure virtue is broadcast everywhere
and the Róng and Yí barbarians accept orders,
then one is the leader controlling the army.
One practices kind-heartedness to win people's hearts.
One practices rectitude so as to impose strict order.
One practises ritual in order to instruct people.
One practices predictable good faith in order to get things carried out in practice.
One metes out rewards in order to encourage people.
One metes out punishments in order to show strictness.
When one practises these six things
this is said to be "accruing benefits".
Thus when one is put in charge of an army one does one's best,
one exhausts one's strength
and one carries out one's charge.
Therefore, when one attacks, one will overcome,
and when one defends oneself, one will be safe.
That is the Way of defending oneself with military force.

div.head: 觀風章第九 Sounding Out the People's Mood

p.seg: When he is sharp of hearing he will get to the bottom of things,
and when he sharp-sighted he sort out underlying principles.
When principles are discriminated he will be zhōng,
and when affairs are sorted out he will have a distinct view of things.
The gentleman will get rid of any personally-partial tendences
and he will put on a straight facial expression.
He will not go against principle so as to do harm to creatures.
He will not be fretful about political constellation and go on to employ those up to their task.
It is the good he associates with
it is the bad he eschews.
If he moves forward in this way there will be success
and if he goes out in this way there will be no resentment against him.
Now if he acts like this
then everyone under Heaven will be diligent in the exercise of their duty
and all the lands will thereby be in peace.

div.head: 保孝行章第十 Taking Care of Filial Conduct

p.seg: If zhōng is not practised
then what one follows is not the way.
Therefore when one does not reach the level of zhōng
one loses one's bearings.
One not only endangers one's person.
The shame will also reach one's parents.
Thus the superior person when exercising his filial piety
will start out from zhōng.
And when he has gone all the way with zhōng,
then good fortune and salary will come to him.
Thus when one has achieved a mindset characterised by consummate loving diligence
so that one nourishes one's parents,
then one's generosity extends to other people.
The government of the enlightened ruler
is such that he avails himself of the straight
and cuts out the deviant.
If something is deviant it is not zhōng,
and if something is zhōng it is straight.
When there is straightness/correctness, on then, does he use the capable.
Therefore as a master he takes good care of theWay and of Virtue,
and he makes the worthy and the capable into his aides.
In internal matters he will harmonise things with civil means,
in international matters he will show his authority by military means.
He will constantly practise ritual and music
and will guard things carrying out administration and punishments???
Therefore he will achieve the great educational transformation and flourishing proper practice,
the barbarians will all flock in to submit to his authority.
Subordinates will feel harmonious satisfaction,
and all the lands will be at peace.
This is what the ruler's ability to employ the right ministers,
the subordinates being zhōng and the superordinates being faithful achieves.

div.head: 廣至理章第十二 Expanding the Perfect Government

p.seg: He keeps his garments unruffled, and they are transformed of themselves,
he holds the position of government but is not possessive of things.
This may be called the ultimate of good government.
When the true king is concerned with perfect government
is it far off?
He does nothing and the world is purified of itself.
He has no suspicions and everyone under heaven naturally has good faith.
He is not biased, and everyone under Heaven is naturally public-spirited.
When one holds precious items in low esteem then the people will get rid of their greed.
When one eschews luxury then people will follow the path of frugality.
If one sets high store by politeness then people will not engage in (undignified) competition.
He supremely roams in the virtue of the sages
and makes this into the apogee of his naturalness.

div.head: 揚聖章第十三 Promoting Sagehood

p.seg: When there is insfufficiency he makes up for it,
whenthere is sageful enlightenment he promotes it.
That is the (minister's ) way of antiquity.
Therefore Yú had virtue
and Jiù Yáo sang his praise.
As for the Way of King Wén,
The Duke of Zhōu sang its praise.
King Xuān reestablished power
and Jífǔ sang his praise.
Therefore when the superior person serves in a flourishing time,
he is bound to promote its image.
The flourishing virtue will then spread to everywhere under Heaven
and it will be transmitted to later ages.
That is indeed zhōng, isn't it?

div.head: 辨忠章第十四 Discriminating Zhōng

p.seg: When you deploy it near to you
then you can peseve your family and your land.
If you deploy it far away,
then you can reach to the outer limits of Heaven and Earth.
Thus when the enlightened king runs his state
he must give first priority to becoming clear about zhōng.
The pronouncements of a superior man
are zhōng and not merely rhetorical.
the pronouncements of a minor person
are rhetorical and they are as if zhōng but not really zhōng.
Those who hear them rarely fail to get confused (by them).
When one is zhōng and is capable of kind-heartedness
then the virtue of the state will be promoted abroad.
When one is zhōng and has the capacity for knowledge
then the policies of the state will be promoted by one.
When one is zhōng but has a capacity for courage>brazenness
then the it is hard to keep the state pure. ????待考
Thus, even if one has the relevant abilities
one's achievements must necessarily flow from zhōng.
When one is kind-hearted but fails to be zhōng
then one is making one's generosity a partial business.
When one is knowledgeable but not zhōng
then one is (just) giving a polite veneer to one's fraudulence.
If one is courageous but not zhōng
then one is (just) changing the modalities of one's rebelliousness/disorderly conduct.
Thus even if one has these capabilities
if one goes about them in ways that are not zhōng then one will fail.
These three things one must not fail be gain analytic clarity about.

div.head: 忠諫章第十五 Zhōng Advice

p.seg: When the subordinate can speak up on matters,
and when the superior has the ability to listen to this,
then the the Way of the King shines brightly.
Remonstrating about what has not yet come out into the open
that is supreme.
Remonstrating about what is already manifest
that is next best.
Remonstrating about something that is a matter of the past only,
that is the lowest kind of remonstration.
If one is opposed to something and does not remonstrate
then one is not a zhōng servant.
As for remonstration it takes its beginning from smooth formulations,
it centers on opposng discourse
and it ends in being prepared to die for one's beliefs
so as to ensure blessings for the ruler,
so as to bring peace to the nation.
There is no greater goodness than that of acting out zhōng.
There is no greater wickedness than that of a failure of zhōng.
When one is zhōng, the benefits will come to one;
when one fails in zhōng then punishments will be applied to one.
The superior person takes good care of the Way
and that is how he takes good care, in the long run, of his blessings.
The minor person is inconstant,
and that is how he traps himself in misfortune.
As for the signs of blessings and disaster
aren't they clear?
If one is not concerned for rendering one's due to the state,
how can one count as zhōng?!
Rendering one's due to the state comes in four kinds:
1. proposing men of worth.
2. offering up plans.
3. establishing meritorious achievements.
4. Promoting benefit.
The worthies are the mainstay of the state.
Plans are the rules followed in the state.
Meritorious achievements are what guides the state along (like a general)????待考
Benefits are what is useful in the state.
It is those who are capable who work towards these things.
The Odes has it:
"No words go unrequited
no virtue goes unrewarded."
How much more the contribution of the zhōng minister to the state?

div.head: 盡忠章第十八 Doing One's Best for zhōng

p.seg: When one uses all one's physical strength this does not go beyond one's physical body.
Whhen one uses all the resources of one's mind then this reverberates through long distances.
Therefore the government of the enlightened king
its main concern is for the hiring of worthy talent.
When worthy ministers give their best for zhōng
then the ruler's virtue will spread widely.
Administration and education becomes admirable by the use of zhōng.
The ruler establishes the teaching
and the ministers and subordinates have things explained for them.
Rituals and music flourish because of zhōng.
The ruler above institutes it.
Punishments and fines become clear through zhōng.
Kind-heartedness and generosity spreads through zhōng.
Then within the Four Seas there will be the music celebrating Great Peace.
Once these blessings are realised
one announces them to the spirits above and the people b elow.
That is why one spreads it in the Yǎ and Sòng Odes,
and passes it on into infinitude.
